author: Erik Larson
title: Latvian Pleads Guilty in U.S. in Seven-Year Hacking Scam
text:
A Latvian hacker pleaded guilty in the U.S. to charges linked to the spread of a computer virus that helped thieves steal data and millions of dollars from online accounts over seven years.
Deniss Calovskis, 30, faces a sentence of as long as two years in prison under a plea agreement he reached with U.S. prosecutors, after he was extradited from Latvia in 2013. He could’ve been sentenced to as long as 10 years.
Calovskis told a U.S. magistrate judge in Manhattan Friday that he “wrote a little part” of the virus code, which became known as the Gozi virus. The virus infected more than a million computers worldwide, including about 17,000 in the U.S., according to prosecutors.
He developed “web injects” that changed the appearance of banking websites when viewed on infected computers, making the Gozi virus more dangerous, the U.S. said. Victims were fooled into providing personal information that was used by others to steal from bank accounts, according to prosecutors.
